captions.text:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every

day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for

answers too, answers to questions about science
and nature and the human body, Earth and the

universe! So we're working with Google and
YouTube to answer ten of the most popular

questions searched for on the internet. This
is the World's Most Asked Questions!
[Intro]

Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups?

People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have

much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of
water, or just holding your breath.

But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place

-- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm.

The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles
you have, if you enjoy things like breathing.

And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract
suddenly.

When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the

membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound.

Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse
me” and get on with your life.

But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to
relax.

To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least
the part that controls your diaphragm.
You can do that in a couple of different ways.

One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the

base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions,
including your heartbeat and your breathing.

Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll
stop constantly zapping your diaphragm.

So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds

delicious, but it’s harder than it sounds.
The act of gulping down those dry granules

can provide just enough confusing stimulus
for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone.

Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon

dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem
a little weird, but your natural breathing

rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels,
and if they get too high, your nervous system

will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make
sure they’re doing their job.

And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like

holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All

of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration,

which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things.

If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating.

And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54%

said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close
second was drinking water, at 37%.

We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do

YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook
or Twitter or in the comments down below,

and we will answer the best questions in a
new video at the end of the month. Don’t

forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for World's
Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more
answers here on SciShow.

title: World's Most Asked Questions: How Can I Get Rid of the Hiccups?

comments.author: Michael Garza

comments.text:
Easy method, effective every time for me;

Immediately after the first hiccup slow you breathing so that you're only 
just getting enough oxygen, keep this up for about 10 seconds and resume 
normal breathing, hiccups should be gone.

After watching this video I think it's because of the increase in CO2 that 
occurs from slowing breathing that allows this method to work.﻿

comments.text:
I CAME here after having the hiccups all night and half a day today.  I 
tried almost everything to get rid of the damn hiccups.  The only thing 
that work was tilting my head all the way back for 20 seconds with mouth 
empty and taking deep breaths through your mouth.  I tried first having the 
mouth full of water and swallowing it but it didn't work for me.  So look 
to the ceiling for 20 seconds and that might work.  Let me know.

Edit:  Had the hiccups on/off for the whole day today after eating anything 
and method above didn't work as the first time.  A half a glass of cold 
chocolate milk got rid of my hiccups immediately the four times I've had it 
today.  Maybe any milk will do.﻿

comments.author: Vivien Ding

comments.text:
A method I swear by is: Instead of trying to "ignore away" your hiccup, 
embrace it. Anticipate it. Focusing on your next hiccup (but not trying to 
actively hiccup) can cause your next hiccup to never come. It takes a lot 
of focus, but it certainly is more convenient than holding your breath or 
guzzling a glass of water. It works most of the time for me. Try it! You 
may be surprised. I think this method also works by confusing the vagus 
nerve.﻿

comments.text:
Anyone notice this when holding your breath to get rid of hiccups? Or is it 
just me?

If I hiccup at all after I start holding my breath, it won't work. So I 
exhale, wait a sec, and try again. Only if I don't hiccup while I'm holding 
my breath will it actually stop the hiccups. Just seems weird if the whole 
point is to increase your CO2 levels, shouldn't it do the same thing even 
if you are hiccuping while holding your breath?﻿

comments.author: realtntuser

comments.text:
I am going to share the cure for the hiccups that will end this symptom for 
everyone. Its called the Crash Position Technique. Basically you sit in a 
straight back chair. Once seated you cross your arms across your chest. You 
then SLOWLY bend over like in the crash position they tell you to get in 
when a plane is going down. Once bent over as far as you can you hold your 
breath and GENTLY squeeze your stomach muscle for a period of 2-5 seconds 
"like your trying to squeeze the air out" then release and breath out 
again. Do this two or three times then SLOWLY raise back up to a seating 
position. Everyone I have shown this technique to has see their hiccups 
disappear instantly. Please be advised I AM NOT A DOCTOR so do this 
technique at your own risk and care should be taken if you have any illness 
that can prevent you from bending over or holding your breath.﻿

comments.text:
My "magic cure" for hiccups involves both of these.

1. Take deep breath
2. Hold for five seconds
3. Force yourself to make three big, dry gulps by swallowing spit
4. Exhale and breathe slowly for a few seconds
5. ?????
6. Profit.

Works pretty much every time for me. I can only think of one major hiccup 
fit that wouldn't go away, and it plagued me for almost an entire day. 
Worst day ever.﻿

comments.text:
The one that's quite common in the UK (or Glasgow anyway) is giving someone 
a fright. If you hear someome hiccup you jump out and shout at them a few 
seconds later. I've tried all the water things and breath-holding and they 
don't work as well as giving a fright. This makes sense for resetting the 
nervous system I think. P.S. you need to avtually give them a fright, don't 
let them know you're going to do it. P.P.S Don't do it to the elderly or 
thosr with heart problems etc.﻿

comments.author: Jimmy Nguyen

comments.text:
Because; E = mc^2 ! If there is less energy, there is less mass! But 
because ' c ' is the speed of light, the amount of energy your house needs 
to be producing must be... *calculating* 407666360000000000 Joules of 
energy. Which is about 931 Billion Joules less then the sun makes per hour. 
Pretty impressive! 
Edit: Actually, you'd be producing even MORE energy, because I forgot to 
square the speed of light!

-

This answer is, of course, absolute rubbish. Maybe it's because you're 
dreaming. If you have a lucid dream, and start bobbing up and down, you'll 
eventually start flying! ˙:D If anyone reads this and has tips on how to
